Hao Qin Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Hui Wan Supervision Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Guofeng Guan Supervision Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, College of Chemical Engineering, Jiangsu National Synergetic Innovation Center for Advanced Materials, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing, China State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering College of Chemical Engineering Jiangsu National Synergetic Innovation Center for Advanced Materials Nanjing Tech University Nanjing China State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, College of Chemical Engineering, Jiangsu National Synergetic Innovation Center for Advanced Materials, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Single atom catalysts have been recently reported as the efficient catalysts for hydroisomerization compared to the conventional nanoparticle catalyst. Despite the fascinating advantage in enhancing the metal activity or reducing the catalyst cost, the long-term stability of the single atom catalyst seemed not that satisfactory, especially when reacting under atmospheric pressure. Herein, Pt single atom catalysts were combined with Cu nanoparticles by different means to explore a new way to improve the catalytic performance. Cu nanoparticles were located away from Pt sites to form a binary catalyst, or acted as the support of Pt atoms to form a single atom alloy (SAA) catalyst. With the binary catalyst Pt1–0.1Cu@CS, the conversion of the n-heptane after time on stream of 50 h increased to 70.3 %, higher than Pt1@CS (47.3 %). Besides, excessive Cu nanoparticles in the binary catalyst were found rather harmful to the catalysis instead. However, the SAA catalyst Pt1Cu@SAPO-11 showed a poor activity in hydroisomerization compared to Pt1@CS, indicating that the alloy structure should go against the activation of reactant. The roles of Pt atoms and Cu nanoparticles in different catalysts were discussed in detail. The reaction mechanism of hydroisomerization was refined with the different functions of the dual metal sites. This work might be instructive for the design of single atom catalysts combined with metal nanoparticles. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Bifunctional catalysis Hydroisomerization Long-term stability Cu nanoparticles Single-atom catalysis Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Hydroisomerization of normal alkanes has drawn great attention in petroleum industry for producing high quality fossil fuels and lubricants. In the last two decades, research mainly focused on the modification of acid materials, especially zeolites. Regulating acid properties or introducing hierarchical pores could improve the hydroisomerization performance of the catalysts to some extent [1–3]. In addition, new hydrogenation components made up of non-precious metals have attracted more attention to find an alternative to replace precious metals. It seems promising in the future to apply a new form of hydrogenation component like Ni [4,5], Ni2P [6], NiCu [7,8], NiWS [9], MoOx [10], MoP [11] and so on. However, these catalysts still had some problems like a relatively poor activity or selectivity. As far as the noble metals (e.g., Pd or Pt) are concerned, catalysts with ultralow Pt loading have recently been reported successively for hydroisomerisation [12]. The atomic dispersion of the precious metal, together with the appropriate location, ensured the high activity of the metal sites. In order to achieve a similar yield, the Pt single-atom catalyst required metal loading as low as only 0.01wt%, reduced by 98 % compared to the conventional Pt nanoparticle catalyst [13]. However, the long-term stability of the Pt single-atom catalyst remained plagued by carbon deposition on precious metals. Encapsulating metal species in the zeolite matrix is a compromised method to prevent the fouling of the metal surface by coke [14–16]. Using a relatively high reaction pressure (10–20 bar) may also help slow the deactivation of the catalyst. Bimetalic nanoparticles or dual atoms have offered more opportunities to enhance the kinetics and multifunctional performance of oxygen reduction/evolution and hydrogen evolution reactions [17,18]. Single-atom sites combined with metal nano-aggregates have also long been reported and gradually attracted increasing attention in recent years [19,20]. Especially, PtCu single atom alloy (SAA) has showed a great potential in propane dehydrogenation [21], glycerol hydrogenolysis [22], preferential oxidation of CO [23] and hydrogenation reactions [24]. In general, Cu nanoparticles played a unique role in the (de)hydrogenation reaction, collaborating with Pt atoms. Herein, an ingenious approach was proposed to restrain the deactivation of noble metal sites wtih the introduction of Cu nanoparticles to prepare a binary catalyst. The introduction of Cu nanoparticles could adjust the reaction course of hydroisomerization. Structurally similar but different from the Pt1Cu SAA catalyst, the binary catalyst was more beneficial to give full play to the catalytic activity of metal sites for (de)hydrogenation [25]. By combining Pt single atoms with Cu nanoparticles, an excellent catalytic performance was obtained, especially in terms of the long-term stability. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The zeolite powder of SAPO-11used in this paper was friendly offered by Nankai Catalyst Plant. Ascorbic acid (AA, 99 %), cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, 99.95 %) and copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, 99.9 %) were supplied by Aladdin. Chloroplatinic acid hexahydrate (H2PtCl6·6H2O, 99 %, Adamas), ammonia water (NH3·H2O, 25–28 %, Lingfeng) and ethanol (99.7 %, Yasheng) were used as received. 2.2 Catalysts synthesis Firstly, 1.68 g Ce(NO3)3·6H2O were mixed with 6 g SAPO-11 zeolite powder and grounded for 20 min. Then the mixture was calcined in air at 400 °C for 4 h to acquire CeO2/SAPO-11, labeled as CS. The CS powder was then impregnated with Cu(NO3)2·3H2O with a Cu loading of 0.1 wt%. After calcination in air at 400 °C, the acquired 0.1Cu@CS was preprocessed by AA with ethanol solution for 4 h The AA solution was then removed by centrifugation, washing and dry at 60 °C overnight. Subsequently, the as-synthesized Pt1 catalyst was prepared by impregnation method with a Pt loading of approximately 0.01 wt%. After aging for 12 h, Pt1–0.1Cu@CS was acquired after calcination in air at 350 °C for 2h. Pt1–1Cu@CS was prepared likewise, except for the Cu content. The synthesis method of the PtCu SAA catalyst was as follows. Typically, 0.252 g Cu(NO3)2·3H2O was dispersed in 6 mL anhydrous ethanol and 0.2 g ascorbic acid was added. After stirring well, ammonia water was added to form a yellowish brown precipitate, whose main component was presumed to be cuprous hydroxide. Subsequently, 6 g of SAPO-11 powder was added and mixed evenly. Then, a certain amount of ethanol solution with chloroplatinic acid was dropped. The nominal Pt loading of the as-synthesized catalyst was 0.04 wt%. The suspension immediately changed from yellowish brown to dark gray. It was assumed that PtCl2–6 was rapidly reduced by Cu+, which led to the further disproportionation and dehydration of metastable CuOH·xH2O to form Pt1@CuO/Cu precursor. The obtained solid was dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 12 h and calcined at 350 °C for 2 h to obtain Pt1@CuO/SAPO-11. Before reaction, it was reduced under hydrogen atmosphere in the reactor to obtain Pt1Cu@SAPO-11. 2.3 Characterizations The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the prepared catalysts were obtained in the 2θ range of 5–80° on a D/Max-2400 diffractometer, equipped with a Cu target (40 kV, 200 mA). N2 physisorption measurements at −196 °C were performed on a Micromeritics Tristar 3000 Surface Area Analyzer. Prior to the measurements, all sample were degassed under vacuum at 200 °C for 6 h. The NH3 chemisorption (NH3-TPD) was conducted on the Micromeritics AutoChem 2920 to measure the acidic amounts. Infrared spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine (Py-IR) was on an EQUINOX55 IR spectrometer to calculate the amounts of Brønsted or Lewis acid sites. The spectra of IR were recorded in the range from 400 to 1700 cm-1 at 150 and 350 °C. The element contents (Ce, Cu and Pt) of the catalysts were determined using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-MS) on a SPECTROGENESISICP spectrometer. All samples were dissolved in aqua regia at 80 °C for 2 h before the tests. Hydrogen programmed temperature reduction (H2-TPR) was performed on the Micromeritics Pulse Chemisorb 2705 unit. During each test, 30 mg catalyst was loaded into the quartz tube reactor. 10 % H2/Ar was injected with a flow rate of 40 mL/min. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were taken on a FEI Tecnai G2 F20 at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Spherical aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) STEM was performed on a JEOL JEM-ARM200F working. 2.4 Catalyst performance test The hydroisomerization of n-heptane (n-C7) took on a stainless fixed-bed reactor. For each experiment, 0.4 g of the catalyst (40–60 mesh) was loaded into the constant temperature zone of the reactor. The catalysts were firstly reduced in situ at 300 °C for 2 h with a H2 flow of 40 mL/min at atmospheric pressure. Subsequently, the reactor was adjusted to the reaction temperature. The hydroisomerization of n-heptane was performed with WHSV = 1.0 h-1 and the molar ratio of H2/n-heptane = 5:1. The hydrocarbon products were analyzed online by a Nuoxi 7890A gas chromatography. The reaction products were divided into two simplified categories: (a)isomers of n-heptane, annotated as i/ii-C7H16 (i-C7); (b)side products, including cracking, hydrogenolysis or aromatization products. The conversion of n-C7 and the selectivity of i-C7 were calculated using the following equations: (1) Conversion ( % ) = The mass of n − C 7 consumed The mass of n − C 7 in feedstock × 100 % (2) Selectivity ( % ) = The mass of i − C 7 formed The mass of n − C 7 consumed × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization As can be seen from Fig. 1 , all catalysts have obvious diffraction peaks at 2θ = 8.1, 9.8, 12.8, 16.1, 20.0, 21.9 and 22.3–23.5°, which belong to the characteristic peaks of SAPO-11. The results indicates that the crystal structure of SAPO-11 zeolite has not been significantly damaged by the introduction of ceria or Cu species. Besides the characteristic peaks of SAPO-11, it can be seen that there is also a characteristic peak attributed to CeO x in Pt1–0.1Cu@CS and Pt1–1Cu@CS catalysts. Due to a low content, no characteristic peaks of Cu or Pt species are observed, indicating that Pt or Cu species are well dispersed in the catalysts. It can be seen from the Table 1 that the specific surface and pore volume of Pt1–0.1Cu@CS, Pt1–1Cu@CS and Pt1Cu@SAPO-11 are generally similar. The results indicates that the introduction of ceria or Cu species retain most of the pore structure of SAPO-11 zeolite. The actual loadings of Ce, Cu or Pt in the catalysts are measured by ICP-MS, listed in Table 2 . The actual metal contents are basically consistent with the nominal loadings. As can be seen from the TEM images (see Fig. 2 ), Cu species or CeO x are present as dark speckles or clear lattice stripes respectively. The size of Cu nanoparticles is approximately 3-4 nm. No Pt nanoparticles or atoms can be found in TEM images due to the low content. The morphology of Pt species in the catalysts is further observed by high-angle toroidal dark-field scanning transmission electron microscope (Fig. 3 ). To the binary catalyst Pt1–0.1Cu@CS, the images of Cu nanoparticles loaded on the zeolite are difficult to be stably captured under the lens. Thus, the lattice stripes of Cu species are not very clear. On the contrary, clear lattice stripes represented CeO x and Pt atoms (bright spots marked out with red circles) can be distinctly found in the Pt1–0.1Cu@CS catalyst. Without the interference of ceria, Cu species are easier to identify in the SAA catalyst Pt1Cu@SAPO-11. Pt atoms can also be easily found on the surface of Cu nanoparticles. Intuitively, from the NH3-TPD plot (Fig. 4 ), Pt1–1Cu@CS and Pt1Cu@SAPO-11 seem to have more strong acid sites than Pt1–0.1Cu@CS. It is worth noting that in the process of the CuO x would be reduced by NH3 when testing, NH3 would be adsorbed by Cu metal and form ammonia-copper complex. When the programmed desorption temperature rises, the ammonia-copper complex will decompose and release the NH3, making the measured acid amount higher. However, it's generally believed that only the acidic sites inside the zeolite matrix have the catalytic activity of skeleton isomerism, while the acid sites on the catalyst outer surface should be of no significance to the shape selective catalysis. Therefore, the introduction of Cu or Ce species may reduce the original acid sites of the SAPO-11 zeolite by covering or blocking. As shown in the Table 3 , the amount of medium and strong acid sites in Pt1–0.1Cu@CS was a bit fewer than that of Pt1Cu@SAPO-11. Although the catalyst Pt1–1Cu@CS seems to have more acid sites than Pt1–0.1Cu@CS as measured, the amount of acid sites with actual catalytic activity should be similar in the two catalysts. The Py-IR results shows that the introduction of Cu species not only increases the acid amount, but also increases the B/L acid ratio (see Table 4 ). However, the catalytic activity for hydroisomerization is determined by both metal sites and B acid sites. Thus, the enhancement of acidity alone does not necessarily mean a significant difference of the catalyst activity. The H2-TPR results is shown in Fig. 5 for Pt1–0.1Cu@CS, Pt1–1Cu@CS and Pt1Cu@SAPO-11 catalysts. The Cu species are of lower content and more dispersed in Pt1–0.1Cu@CS. Therefore the interaction between Cu species and ceria is stronger [26] and the ceria plays a role in stabilizing Cu species. The reduction peak at about 280 °C corresponds to the co-reduction of Cu and Ce species, the main contribution of the peak area attributed to the latter. On the contrary, the reduction peak of Pt1–1Cu@CS is at about 250 °C due to the reduction of Cu species. The reduction peaks of Pt1–1Cu@CS at 600–700 °C should be the bulk phase reduction of the ceria. To Pt1Cu@SAPO-11 catalyst, Cu oxides need to be reduced by hydrogen radical with stronger reducibility, produced by Pt atoms. Thus, the reduction of Cu species occurs from the Pt atoms and extends to the surrounding. But hydrogen radicals may associate and desorption on the reduced Cu metal surface, delaying the subsequent reduction of the rest of Cu species. So the reduction peak of Pt1Cu@SAPO-11 is relatively gentle and delayed to 300 °C. In addition, Cu2+ in the zeolite matrix is more difficult to be reduced at 450 °C. The H2-TPR results show that the reducibility of Pt1Cu SAA are not that satisfactory as Pt1@CeO x . 3.2 Catalytic performace evaluation Although the Pt loading of the Pt1Cu@SAPO-11 catalyst is much higher than that of the binary catalysts, the catalytic activity of the three catalysts at 340 °C have no significant difference. As shown in Fig. 6 , the conversions of n-heptane with the three catalysts are about 74 % at 340 °C. This indicates that the specific activity of Pt sites in SAA catalysts should be much lower than the binary catalysts. It is more conducive to separate Cu nanoparticles from Pt atoms for the catalysis of hydroisomerization. Besides, the conversion of n-heptane shows a decline after 360 °C on some catalysts. This is because too high a temperature can lead to the agglomeration of Pt atoms, resulting in an irreversible deactivation of the catalysts. The Pt1–1Cu@CS catalyst has more metal sites than Pt1–0.1Cu@CS, but its apparent activity has no obvious difference with the latter. Because the catalytic performance for n-heptane hydroisomerization is determined by both metal sites and acid sites. The excess metal sites does not necessarily lead to an increase in activity. Besides, under a higher reaction temperature, the carbon deposition reaction would be more severe. Especially, when the reaction temperature went up to 360 °C, the conversion of n-heptane with Pt1–0.1Cu@CS slightly exceeded that of Pt1–1Cu@CS instead perhaps due to a less severe carbon accumulation. Thus, carbon deposition could not be ignored as an interruption to measure the catalyst activity in that case. In terms of the long-term stability of the catalysts (see Fig. 7 ), the deactivated rate of Pt1@CS [27] without loading any Cu nanoparticles was the fastest. Meanwhile, the decrease of the conversion of n-heptane with Pt1–0.1Cu@CS was obviously slower than Pt1–1Cu@CS along with the time on stream. Pt1–0.1Cu@CS has the best stability, where the conversion of n-heptane slowly decreases from an initial 75 % to 70 % after 50 h Without changing the loading amount of the precious metal, a handy modification can extend the lifetime of the catalyst drastically. From the point of view of isomer selectivity, Pt1–0.1Cu@CS also maintains the optimal state. Due to less severe deactivation of Pt1–0.1Cu@CS, Pt atoms can provide more hydrogen radicals to reduce the residence time of alkane intermediates on the catalyst surface. However, the isomer selectivity with Pt1–1Cu@CS, having more Cu loadings, turns into its opposite because the presence of excess Cu nanoparticles might enhance the reverse reaction of hydrogen dissociation. Thus, excess Cu nanoparticles would negatively affect Pt atoms’ ability to dissociate hydrogen. It would be very necessary to reasonably consider the synergistic effect of the different metal sites to catalyze hydrogen-related reactions. Due to the higher Pt loading (0.041 wt%), the deactivation of the SAA catalyst Pt1Cu@SAPO-11 was slower than that of Pt1@CS. But it was still faster than that of the binary catalysts loaded with Cu nanoparticles. In addition, the isomer selectivity of Pt1Cu@SAPO-11 was also the most disappointing among the catalysts. These results show that the content of Cu nanoparticles and their location relationship with Pt atoms both have a profound effect on the catalytic performance of the catalysts. 3.3 Reaction mechanism Herein, how the quantity and location of Cu nanoparticles affect the catalytic performance of the catalyst is discussed in detail from the perspective of reaction mechanism. The reaction network of n-heptane hydroisomerization on Pt1–0.1Cu@CS is shown in Fig. 8 . The main steps in hydroisomerization of n-heptane with the catalysts are listed as the following equation: (3) H 2 → Pt 1 2 H * (4) n − C 7 H 16 ⇄ Metal n − C 7 H 14 = + 2 H * (5) n − C 7 H 14 = → Acid i / ii − C 7 H 14 = (6) i / ii − C 7 H 14 = → Acid n − C 3 H 6 = + i − C 4 H 8 = (7) i / ii − C 7 H 14 = + 2 H * ⇄ Metal i / ii − C 7 H 16 (8) n − C 3 H 6 = + 2 H * ⇄ Metal n − C 3 H 8 (9) i − C 4 H 8 = + 2 H * ⇄ Metal i − C 4 H 10 (10) 2 H * → Metal H 2 (11) i / ii − C x H y = → Pt 1 C + yH * Here, “Metal” stands for both Pt atoms and Cu nanoparticles. “H*” refers to hydrogen radicals. “C” means carbon deposition. As Eq. (3), Pt atoms are the crucial channel for hydrogen atoms to enter from the gas phase to the surface of the catalyst, and is a key step for the whole reaction network to proceed normally. Otherwise, without sufficient hydrogen radicals involved, the hydrocarbon intermediates cannot complete the subsequent reaction as Eqs (7)–(9), which need to consume hydrogen radicals. The alkane dehydrogenation reaction also produces some hydrogen radicals as Eq. (4), so only a small amount of Pt single atoms are needed to supplement the hydrogen radicals for the reaction. However, carbon deposition reactions can also occur on the surface of Pt atoms, as Eq. (11), resulting in faster deactivation of the catalysts without Cu nanoparticles. Cu nanoparticles can activate the reactant, n-heptane, which dehydrogenates to form n-C7H14 = as Eq. (4). Furthermore, they can make i/ii-C7H14 = hydrogenate to saturation to produce the corresponding isoheptane as Eq. (7). Unlike Pt atoms, no carbon deposition would occur on the surface of Cu nanoparticles because Cu nanoparticle binds the intermediates, i/ii-C7H14 =, more weakly than Pt species [25]. Although the presence of Cu nanoparticles cannot completely avoid the carbon deposition on Pt atoms, the competitive adsorption of intermediates between Cu nanoparticles and Pt atoms would slow down the catalysts’ deactivation. This is the reason why the binary catalyst with Cu nanoparticles has better long-term stability than Pt1@CS. To restrain the deactivation ultimately, the intermediates i/ii-C7H14 = should also get hydrogen radicals sufficiently and timely as Eq. (7). H2 dissociation is expected to be as fast as possible to prevent hydrocarbon intermediates from staying too long on the catalyst surface. Therefore, Cu content cannot be excessive to avoid the undesired reassociation of hydrogen radicals as Eq. (10). This is the reason why Pt1–0.1Cu@CS catalyst has a better long-term stability than Pt1–1Cu@CS. Similarly, the effect of location relationship on the catalytic performance can also be understood by network analysis of Pt1Cu@SAPO-11 as shown in Fig. 9 . The Cu sites do not have any particular adverse effect on the elementary reactions involved in alkanes, compared to the binary catalysts. However, the hydrogen radicals dissociated from the Pt sites would inevitably undergo a large number of association reactions on the surrounding Cu surface. This leads to a severe shortage of hydrogen radicals on the catalyst surface, resulting in a huge disadvantage in both catalyst activity and product selectivity. Furthermore, the SAA catalyst is also quickly deactivated. Conventionally speaking, the hydroisomerization catalysts are defined as bifunctional catalysts with both metal and acid functions. The proximity and synergy between the two sites have been discussed in depth [28–30]. However, it is noteworthy that the metal function should be divided into both activation of hydrocarbons and hydrogen, named as dehydrogenation and dissociation respectively. Cu nanoparticles barely dissociate the hydrogen into radicals, looking unnecessary for catalysis. Nonetheless, Cu nanoparticles do not support the carbon deposition reaction either due to a weak bond to hydrocarbons. Meanwhile, Cu nanoparticles take on partial responsibility of hydrocarbons’ (de)hydrogenation. The Pt single atoms anchored by ceria in our catalysts were apparently separated from Cu nanoparticles spatially. Therefore, Cu nanoparticles are speculated to participates in the reaction as active metal sites, rather than play a role in electronic modification to Pt atoms. 4 Conclusions With the Pt single atoms, the activity of the catalysts can be greatly improved and the cost of noble metal can be reduced drastically. The deactivation of single atom catalyst becomes the main problem restricting its further application in hydroisomerization. Herein, Cu nanoparticles are introduced into the Pt single atom catalyst to inhibit the catalyst deactivation for the first time. A proper Cu content (approximately 0.1 wt%) would improve catalytic activity and long-term stability. However, Cu nanoparticles are not suitable to be directly used as the support of Pt atoms. The roles of Pt atoms and Cu nanoparticles are discussed in detail, involving in both hydroisomerization and catalyst deactivation. This work may be instructive for the design of single atom catalysts combined with metal nano-aggregates for efficient hydrogen-involved catalysis. coredata.dc:description: Single atom catalysts have been recently reported as the efficient catalysts for hydroisomerization compared to the conventional nanoparticle catalyst. Despite the fascinating advantage in enhancing the metal activity or reducing the catalyst cost, the long-term stability of the single atom catalyst seemed not that satisfactory, especially when reacting under atmospheric pressure. Herein, Pt single atom catalysts were combined with Cu nanoparticles by different means to explore a new way to improve the catalytic performance. Cu nanoparticles were located away from Pt sites to form a binary catalyst, or acted as the support of Pt atoms to form a single atom alloy (SAA) catalyst. With the binary catalyst Pt1–0.1Cu@CS, the conversion of the n-heptane after time on stream of 50 h increased to 70.3 %, higher than Pt1@CS (47.3 %). Besides, excessive Cu nanoparticles in the binary catalyst were found rather harmful to the catalysis instead. However, the SAA catalyst Pt1Cu@SAPO-11 showed a poor activity in hydroisomerization compared to Pt1@CS, indicating that the alloy structure should go against the activation of reactant. The roles of Pt atoms and Cu nanoparticles in different catalysts were discussed in detail. The reaction mechanism of hydroisomerization was refined with the different functions of the dual metal sites. This work might be instructive for the design of single atom catalysts combined with metal nanoparticles.
